video.title: Ni No Kuni 2: Revenant Kingdom (Zero Punctuation)

captions.text:
You remember Ni No Kuni 1: Wrath of the White
Witch Who Doesn&#39;t Show Up Until, Like, Right
At The End.

It was that heartwarming Studio Ghibli JRPG
about a little boy who fucking stone cold

kills his mum and then skips town so he can
blow his allowance on pixie dust and party

it up in fantasy land with two older kids
and a gonk.
Well, they&#39;ve put out a sequel to it.

One that&#39;s basically completely unconnected
to the first one, &#39;cos the protagonist of

that is presumably stumbling along the side
of a highway by now in a drug-addled haze.

Ni No Kuni 2: Revenant Kingdom is sadly not
a game about a society run by rocket launcher

wielding giant skeletons, but a typically
twee cartoon fantasy JRPG with a slightly
off-putting title.

Now, I wasn&#39;t sure I was gonna do this game
because you know what I&#39;m like with JRPGs

that aren&#39;t called Earthbound or Persona 5
- I&#39;ll be rolling my eyes dismissively at

the first sign of hairdoes that look like
they were crafted out of brightly coloured

mashed potato by an extremely bored child
who can&#39;t leave the table.

But precisely thirty seconds into the plot,
I had a feeling I was going to have to talk

about this one, firstly in a review and then
maybe at some kind of inquest into what the

fuck Japan has been playing at for the last
thirty years or so.
So here&#39;s how the story starts.

The President of the United States is on his
way to a summit of the UN when the city he&#39;s

driving through gets hit by a direct nuclear
strike.

Don&#39;t worry, you didn&#39;t just turn over two
pages at once, this is still Ni No Kuni 2.

Moments before death the President is transported
to a fantasy world, specifically to the bedchamber
of a little prince boy wearing cat ears.

Well, that&#39;s one explanation, anyway, but
maybe you should save it for the hearing,
Mr. President.

Also, he gets de-aged about thirty years for
no particular reason except it&#39;s the law that

JRPG protagonists can&#39;t look old enough to
buy health potion without getting carded.

Fortuitously enough the royal castle is in
the middle of a coup and the President rescues

the prince from the ensuing purge by drawing
his sidearm and straight icing some motherfuckers,

before deciding maybe he shouldn&#39;t go 100%
Ash Williams on this shit and picks up a sword
to ice motherfuckers with instead.

At this point I was more on board than a superglue
enthusiast cheating at a surf competition,

but I got a sinking feeling after the President
gets the deposed prince - Evan, he&#39;s called,

which you&#39;ll note is very nearly Naive spelt
backwards - to safety and the prince declares

he&#39;s going to found a much better kingdom
with blackjack and hookers.

I was like, &quot;Oh, don&#39;t you fucking dare make
this little twerp the main character now,
game.
I want to be President Kickass.

He&#39;s smart and capable with a hint of darkness
to him and all in all was probably written

by someone with archaic ideas of what it takes
to be a world leader.&quot;

But then again the protagonist does need to
go through an arc and President Kickass is

about as arced out as a McDonalds logo from
the word go, so fine, we&#39;ll play it your way,

King Evan, but just so you know, the instant
we unlock more characters than the standard

party size allows then you&#39;re going straight
on the fucking bench.

The guy in charge spearheading the adventuring
party didn&#39;t make sense in Star Trek and it
doesn&#39;t make sense now.

President Kickass agrees to be Evan&#39;s chief
advisor because hey, turns out statecraft

is his primary skill set and it&#39;s not like
he&#39;s got any major dental appointments coming

up, so the pair set out to find a new land
and some subjects who&#39;ll agree to join their
treehouse club for cool dudes.

Which turns out to be slightly easier than
it sounds.

There&#39;s a big old chunk of resource-rich,
highly defensible land right around the corner

that for some reason no one has claimed, maybe
someone saw the unpopular kids hanging around

it and so the fantasy united nations declared
it &#39;that smelly land for gaylords&#39;.

Sadly, after the effective opening hook that
is President Kickass the plot settles into

achingly typical fantasy JRPG territory, Evan
and friends travel from city to city, sort

out major civic problem du jour, pick up a
party member, fight a boss and then all aboard

the ship or the airship or whatever you need
to unlock the way to the next city.

Every city is having its own issues with a
tyrant ruler but of course the only reason

any of them are doing bad things is because
the big baddie has corrupted them with wibbly
wobbly purple badness juice.

When I say &#39;bad&#39; I suppose I mean &#39;contrary
to Evan&#39;s interests&#39; because I don&#39;t think

he wants to be throwing stones in the good/bad
area considering that his stated goal is to

take over the entire motherfucking world and
create eternal peace.

Yeah, sure, Evan, YOU just want peace, it&#39;s
all these unhelpful types who don&#39;t want to

be subjugated that are stirring up the trouble,
you&#39;d have peace in no time if only they&#39;d

calm down and hold still while President Kickass
stabs them to death.

So Ni No Kuni 2 is juggling a few layers of
gameplay.

First of all, standard combat, which is a
full on real time hack and slash affair rather
than turn-based battling,

or indeed that godawful hybrid system Ni No
Kuni 1 had which was like being unable to

decide if you&#39;re gonna walk or take the subway
train so you try to do both at once with different
feet.

You&#39;ve got your light attack, heavy attack,
dodge and block, but 90% of the combat is

a visually cluttered punch-up with groups
of weak dudes so you can get through most

of it perfectly well just mashing attack and
occasionally doing a big clearing special

move when they start getting too fresh and
you need personal space.

At other times, like in boss fights, you might
as well not bother with blocking at all since

getting into block stance on the spur of the
moment takes, I&#39;d say, without hyperbole,

about five thousand years, plus it doesn&#39;t
absorb everything and only works from a specific
angle, like a very badly designed tampon.

So that&#39;s the basic combat, but there&#39;s also
the kingdom management element, which isn&#39;t

terribly deep; sadly you don&#39;t get to set
the tax rate or oversee the laying of the
poo pipes.

It&#39;s more your facebook management game thing
- build stuff to earn money to build more

stuff to earn more money, so management in
the sense of tying a piece of string to a
slug so you can &#39;manage&#39; it along a drainpipe.

Your kingdom also generates a constant stream
of vendor trash inventory that you can collect

on the off chance that one of the games&#39; several
trillion fetch quests will ask for some of
it.

Lastly there are also skirmish battles that
play like a basic real time strategy where

all your units are glued to the same lazy
Susan.

It&#39;s not terrible as gameplay interludes go,
but that&#39;s kind of what it and a lot of the

kingdom management stuff feels like - an interlude,
rather than interconnected.

The thing is, as the game wore on I inevitably
started to feel underlevelled for the main

story missions so I took time off from the
plot to run through some side stuff and after

three hours of aggressive citizen headhunting,
toy soldier battles and fetching people&#39;s

sandwiches, I realised - hang on, my standard
combat ability has improved by basically fuck
all, so what was the bloody point.

Overall Ni No Kuni 2 feels a bit hacked out
as sequels go - you&#39;ll note the conspicuously

small monster variety and conspicuously absent
animated Studio Ghibli cutscenes like what

the first one had - and the story runs the
gamut between total predictability and utter
nonsense.

The conclusion to the ocean city segment leaps
to mind.

There was a disaster but the queen is keeping
the city alive with a magic time loop and

a giant staring eyeball - what are you on
about, fishy tits?

You forbid love because if the population
changes then the city explodes or something.

Well, I just headhunted like twelve guys from
your main square so you&#39;re probably fucked?

Have you considered solving everything with
the power of friendship?
Usually works for me.
Fucking cheaper than fossil fuels.
